Award.AwardTitle: Structural variation of the nitrogen-fixing heterocyst: Addressing the role of gas permeability in evolutionary divergence
Award.AbstractNarration: Nitrogen (N) fixation by microorganisms contributes enormous quantities of usable, life-sustaining N to natural and agricultural systems each year. Because oxygen irreversibly poisons the N-fixation machinery, managing oxygen exposure is a central problem for N-fixing organisms, which use oxygen to make energy. The cyanobacterial heterocyst is a specialized cell designed to provide both sufficient energy and an environment favorable for N fixation. Here, the investigators propose to use the heterocyst as a model to address how changing temperature shapes the form and function of biological structures, which manipulate gas exchange with the environment. Specifically, the investigators will combine chemical, physiological, and genetic approaches to test how naturally-occurring variation in heterocyst architecture associated with environmental temperature impacts the temperature-dependence of heterocyst function through the modification of oxygen flow into the heterocyst. The project promises novel and general insights into how this ecologically and economically important structure is affected by increasing temperature and its capacity for an evolutionary response in the face of environmental change. Because the heterocyst is also currently the best model for producing hydrogen energy from light, the project outcomes will have implications for how to engineer a reliable and affordable source of hydrogen. The project integrates research and education through mentoring and outreach at diverse levels, including a field course in Yellowstone that reveals the interdependence of microorganisms and wildlife for controlling N availability in the world's first national park.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nitrogen (N) fixation by microorganisms contributes enormous quantities of usable, life-sustaining N to natural and agricultural systems each year.  Because oxygen irreversibly poisons the N-fixation machinery, managing oxygen exposure is a central problem for N-fixing organisms which use oxygen to make energy; the cyanobacterial heterocyst is a specialized cell designed to provide both sufficient energy and an environment favorable for N fixation.  For this award, we used the heterocyst as a model to address how changing temperature shapes the form and function of biological structures which manipulate gas exchange with the environment.  Specifically, we combined chemical, physiological and genetic approaches to test how naturally-occurring variation in heterocyst architecture associated with environmental temperature impacts the temperature-dependence of heterocyst function through the modification of oxygen flow into the heterocyst. 

The project revealed novel insights into how this ecologically and economically important structure is affected by increasing temperature and its capacity for an evolutionary response in the face of environmental change. One of our most important and surprising findings was that the genetic differences responsible for differences in heterocyst performance were generally very ancient. This runs counter to the conventional view of how bacteria adapt to the environment, which emphasizes the role of recent, repeatable and transient change (as in the evolution of antibiotic resistance, for example). In fact, some of this genetic variation has persisted for more than 50 million years, the most extreme example in bacteria to our knowledge. Our study implies that the persistence of ancient variation may play a more important role in the maintenance and distribution of microbial diversity at both local and global scales than has previously been recognized. In addition, our discovery of genetic and structural mechanisms by which nature has modified the heterocyst to control oxygen flow has implications for how to engineer a reliable and affordable source of hydrogen, because the heterocyst is currently the best model for producing hydrogen energy from light. 

The project integrated research and education through mentoring and outreach at diverse levels. This included training and support of award-winning research in the laboratory at the postdoctoral, graduate, undergraduate and high school levels. To inspire the next generation of biologists, we integrated material on the importance of nitrogen fixation, how a heterocyst is put together and how it works as part of a microscopy-based interactive module for K-6 children on microbial diversity of local streams. This was delivered at a Magic of Chemistry Summer Camp organized by SpectrUM, our local interactive science museum, and at a local summer day camp. Members of the lab group also developed and routinely participated in SpectrUM outreach sessions, both during normal museum hours and for its monthly First Friday Missoula open house, as well as educational modules on concepts in evolution and adaptation for high school independent study programs.
